variant.question: A flight is operating in IMC under IFR, exactly on the current flight plan route At 1836 UTC the radar controller gives the following instruction??Turn to heading 050, maintain heading 050 until further advised?? This message is acknowledged At 1837 UTC a two way communication failure occursRadio communication cannot be re-established The procedure to be followed is to

options.text: return to the current flight plan route.
continue on heading 050.
continue on heading 050 for 15 minutes.
continue on heading 050 for 30 minutes.

variant.question: A pilot is vectored in trajectory of a CB. The pilot can see in his weather radar display a large active cell. According to SERA, the pilot:

options.text: Can request to deviate and follow a different course, ATC will then use the new pilot track to give vectors.
Can fly 5 NM right and climb 1000 ft.
Can fly 5 NM left and descend 1 000 ft.
Can request an amended clearance to overfly the CB.

variant.question: If you have been intercepted by another aircraft, what is the phrase if you do not know your current position?

options.text: AM LOST
LOST INSTRUMENT
LOST POSITION
NEED POSITION INFORMATION

variant.question:
Flying exactly on your current flight plan route at 18:36 UTC you receive and acknowledge the following instruction from the radar controller:
'Turn immediately, continue heading 050° until further advised.'
At 18:37 UTC you find out that radio communication cannot be established again. You have to return to your current flight plan route:

options.text: in the most direct manner.
with an intercept angle of 20° or more.
with an intercept angle of at least 30°.
with an intercept angle not exceeding 45°.

variant.question: An aircraft experiencing radio communication failure on an IFR flight in IMC under radar control is assumed to:

options.text:
Maintain the last assigned speed and level, or the minimum safe altitude, if this is higher,
for a period of 7 minutes then proceed in accordance with the current flight plan to the designated navigation aid serving the destination aerodrome

Maintain the last assigned speed and level, or the minimum safe altitude, if this is higher,
for a period of 7 minutes then divert to the most suitable aerodrome according to the route of flight
Proceed to an area from where the flight can be continued according to the visual flight rules
Execute a VMC approach at the nearest suitable aerodrome

variant.question: A radial is:

options.text: a magnetic bearing extending from a VOR station.
a magnetic bearing to or from a VOR station, depending on whether the aircraft is inbound or outbound to or from the VOR.
a magnetic bearing to a VOR station.
a QDM.

variant.question: One of the functions ensured by a radar control unit for the provision of approach control service is

options.text: to conduct surveillance and precision radar approaches.
To provide instructions in order to reduce separations minima, if accepted by the pilots.
to apply a horizontal separation less then 5 NM.
To apply a reduced vertical separation of 500 feet between IFR flights and VFR flights.

variant.question: Shortly after reaching the cruising altitude at FL320, the pilot notices that the transponder has failed. However, a functioning transponder is required for the route. According to ICAO Doc 8168 and the EU SERA Regulation, the pilot expects ATC to:

options.text: Attempt to provide for continuation of the flight to the destination.
Suggest limiting your altitude to below FL285 and returning to your point of departure.
Recommend you to return to your point of departure.
Recommend you to land at the nearest suitable aerodrome.

variant.question: During a flight in controlled airspace where carriage of a transponder is mandatory, the onboard transponder fails and the pilot informs ATC of the situation. Which of the following is correct according to ICAO Doc 8168?

options.text: ATC units shall attempt to provide for continuation to the destination.
The pilot shall land at the nearest suitable aerodrome.
The aircraft must leave the controlled airspace and reroute in uncontrolled airspace.
Return to the departure aerodrome is required.

variant.question: An aircraft is receiving radar vectors. Upon intercepting an assigned radial, the controller advises you that you are on the airway and to "resume own navigation". This phrase means that:

options.text: you are to resume responsibility for your own navigation.
radar services are terminated and you will be responsible for position reports.
you are still in radar contact, but must make position reports.
you are to contact the centre at the next reporting point.

variant.question:
Consider the following forms of position information passed on to an aircraft by radar service. Which option lists the correct forms for passing such position information?
1. Direction (using points of the compass) and distance from a known position, 
 2. Direction and distance from the centre line of an ATS route, 
 3. True track and distance to the centre line of an ATS route 
 4. Magnetic track and distance to a significant point, 
 5. True track and distance to a significant point.

options.text: 1 and 5.
2 and 4.

variant.question: Which of the following statements about a radar advisory service is true?

options.text: The pilot must consider that the controller is not aware of all traffic within their airspace.
Clearances are provided to increase safety in controlled airspaces.
Such service is only provided for controlled aircraft in upper airspace.
Such service is only provided on and in close proximity to aerodromes.

variant.question: Which of the following statements about a radar advisory service is true?

options.text: The pilot must consider that the controller is not aware of all traffic within their airspace.
Radar service does not mean the atc controller can see you visually on a screen
Such service is only provided on and in close proximity to aerodromes.
Clearances are provided to increase safety in controlled airspaces.

variant.question: The expression `Radar Contact` in RT phraseology means..

options.text: the radar identity of the aircraft has been established.
the pilot does not have to follow up and report the position of the aircraft.
position reports may be abbreviated.
the aircraft is subject to positive control and separation from other traffic will be provided.

variant.question: Except otherwise established by the appropriate ATS authority a Surveillance Radar Approach (SRA) shall be terminated at a distance from the touchdown of:

options.text: 2 NM
3 NM
4 NM
5 NM

variant.question: When radar identification of an aircraft has been achieved, the radar controller shall;

options.text: inform the pilot.
communicate with the pilot only when work load permits.
request the pilot to squawk ident.
inform the pilot only when identification had been achieved using primary radar.

variant.question: The surveillance radar approach (SRA) shall be terminated at a distance of 2 NM from the touchdown except when as determined by the appropriate ATS authority, the accuracy of the radar equipment permits to be continued to a prescribed point less than 2 NM from the touchdown. In this case distance and level information shall be given at each:

options.text: 0.5 NM
1 NM
1.5 NM

variant.question: A complete position report transmitted by radiotelephony shall contain the following elements of information in the order listed...

options.text: 1- Aircraft identification, 2- position, 3- time, 4- flight level or altitude, 5- next position and time over, 6- ensuing significant point.
1- Aircraft identification, 2- position, 3- time, 4- flight level or altitude, 5- next position, 6- time over.
1- Aircraft identification, 2- position, 3- time, 4- true air speed, 5- flight level or altitude, 6- next position and time over.
1- Aircraft identification, 2- position, 3- flight level or altitude, 4- time, 5- next position and time over, 6- ensuing significant point.

variant.question: Due to two inoperative VORs, aircraft are vectored to runway 14. What will the controller say when the vectoring is terminated?

options.text: Resume own navigation, position is ... proceed via ... for ILS approach runway 14.
Only “resume own navigation”.
Radar vectoring terminated, position is ... proceed via ... for ILS approach runway 14.
Radar vectors terminated, resume previously assigned navigation.

variant.question: When does Air Traffic Control Services have the responsibility to prevent collisions with terrain?

options.text: When a flight in accordance with IFR is vectored by radar.
ATS only provides prevention when an aircraft is flying IFR in IMC.
ATS never prevent collisions with terrain.
Always when ATS are provided.

variant.question: An aircraft is being radar vectored. What instructions will the controller give to the pilot when vectoring is terminated?

options.text: Resume own navigation, position 15 NM South of VOR XY.
Resume own navigation.
Radar service terminated.
Resume previous navigation, position 15 NM South of VOR XY.

variant.question: Which does ATC Term "radar contact" signify?

options.text: Your aircraft has been identified on the radar display and radar flight instructions will be provided until radar identification is terminated.
You will be given traffic advisories until advised that the service has been terminated or that radar contact has been lost.
ATC is receiving your transponder and will furnish vectors and traffic advisories until you are advised that contact has been lost.
Your aircraft has been identified and you will receive separation from all aircraft while in contact with this radar facility.

variant.question: What do ATC provide to an aircraft during radar vectoring?

options.text: Headings to fly.
Tracks to fly.
VOR radials to intercept.
Attitudes to fly.

variant.question: When conducting a surveillance radar approach (SRA), the radar controller shall terminate the SRA, except as determined by the appropriate ATS authority, at a distance of:

options.text: 2 NM from touchdown.
1 NM from touchdown.
3 NM from touchdown.
2.5 NM from touchdown.

variant.question: What is meant when departure control instruct you to "resume own navigation" after you have been vectored to an airway?

options.text: FL 40
FL 35
FL 25
FL 20

variant.question: Where a "Secondary Surveillance Radar" (SSR) is not available (PSR is used), radar identification may be achieved by one of the following procedures:

options.text: to instruct the pilot to execute one or more heading changes of 30° or more.
to instruct the pilot to execute one or more heading changes of 45°.
to instruct the pilot to execute one or more heading changes of 20° or more.
to instruct the pilot to execute one or more heading changes of 10°.

variant.question: You fly a lateral offset 20 NM to the left to avoid weather, while your planned route makes a right turn. After you are cleared of weather, ATC advises you to continue own navigation again. What shall you do?

options.text: Regain track to the coming waypoint.
Ask ATC where to proceed.
Continue with 20 NM offset.
Fly a standard holding pattern at the next waypoint.

variant.question: When radar identification of aircraft has been achieved, the radar controller shall:

options.text: inform the aircraft prior to issue of any instructions or advice based on the use of radar.
inform the aircraft only if communication workload permits.
inform the aircraft only if radar identification has been achieved without availability of SSR.
not be obliged to inform the aircraft before issuing any instructions based on the use of radar.

variant.question: When a surveillance radar approach (SRA) is to be continued to the threshold of the runway transmission should not be interrupted for intervals of more than five seconds while the aircraft is within a distance of:

options.text: 4 NM from the touchdown.
2 NM from the touchdown.
3 NM from the touchdown.
1.5 NM from the touchdown.

variant.question: When "Secondary Radar" is used, an aircraft may be identified by one of the following procedures:

options.text: observation of compliance with an instruction to operate transponder from "ON" to "STBY" and back to "ON".
request the pilot to set transponder to the "ON" position.
request the pilot to switch transponder from "ON" to "STBY" position.
request the pilot to set transponder to the "OFF" position.
